Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Flow Assessment in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Trial_Design.evidence: The study did not involve randomisation or blinding.

Participants.evidence: This observational nationwide cohort study included 18,211 patients who underwent first-time isolated CABG in Sweden from 2013 to 2020, identified from the SWEDEHEART registry.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the effect of preoperative physiological flow assessment on mid-term outcomes in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of all-cause mortality, stroke, new myocardial infarction, new coronary angiography, and new revascularization, measured over a median follow-up of 3.6 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The study did not involve randomisation or blinding.

Blinding.evidence: The study did not involve randomisation or blinding.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The study did not involve randomisation or blinding.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the total cohort, 2,869 patients (15.8%) underwent preoperative flow assessment

Result_Outcome.evidence: preoperative flow assessment was associated with a higher risk of new angiography (adjusted hazard ratio [aHR] 1.32, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.08–1.62, P = .008) and new revascularization (aHR 1.55, 95% CI 1.18–2.04, P = .002)

Harms.evidence: There were no significant differences in mortality, post-discharge myocardial infarction, or stroke between groups.
